cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
London
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: To-day's plague bulletin records a fresh case at Alexandria, the victim being a native living at Kom el Dik.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail for Barope, viâ Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 8.80 a.m. on Monday,

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: The imports of coal from January 1 to June 21 amounted to 594,103 tone, as compared with 434,097 tons during the same period last
year.

div.head: Cairo Compositors.
div.p: A meeting of the compositors of the Cairo papers will be held tomorrow morning, when & permanent commission, which will in future disouss all questions concerning the composi tors with the managers of the papers, will be appointed.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: This evening the Italian operetta company | will present 20.000 Leghe intorno al Globo, tounded on Jules Verne's popular work. Tomorrow afternoon, there will be a matinée performance of The Geisha, at reduced prices, which should draw a bamper house.

div.head: Maternity Home.
div.p: We should like to appeal to our readers on behalf of the small crècbe just formed at the Maternity Home by its most excellent matron, Mme Antonio, who is doing very good work. The orèche greatly needs a few perambulators to take the infants out from day to day, and any of our readers who possess old perambulators for which they have no further use would being doing the crèche and, through the crèche, the publio a good turn, by handing them over to Mme Antonio.

div.head: New Bathing Station.
div.p: Devotees of sea-bathing in Alexandria--and their name is legion-will welcome the inanga. ration, which takes place to-day, of the new bathing station at Chstby. It is true that the batbs at San Stefano and Mex are all that could be desired, but distance and the time necessary to go to these baths undoubtedly preolude a large number of bathers from indulging in their favourite pastime as often as they otherwise would. The Chstby baths have therefore come to fill a decided want- resort within easy reach of the city, but which at the same time supplies all the desiderata of bathers. Taking a car at the city terminus, you are transported in the space of five mioutes to this newly-erected casino, where the bracing sea a breeze is to be had in all its freshness. A E tramway station has been made almost opposite i the baths, which provide accommodation for d 150 bathers, there being 70 gentlemen's and 80 | ladies' cabins, all airy and open to the sea, The beach is sandy and the depth of water varies from zero to 2 metres on the men's side and to 1) metres on the ladies' side. Between the two sides a large terrape bas been erected where on a buffet bas been installed. For those who wish for nothing more than a "blow" in these warm months, the baths will be deoided boon,

Ahmed Paoba Yehis entertained at a tea party yesterday H.E. the Regent, Sir R Wingate Pacha, Msz'oum Pacha, Pakhry Pacha, Abani Paobs, Ghalib Pachs Sardar, Mahmoad Pacha Shukri, and Mastapha Pacha Ibady, Govərnor of Alexandria.
H. E. Hussein Pacha Fakhry, Minister of Pablic Works, will leave for England next Monday

M. de la Boulinière, French Diplomatic Agent and Consal-General in Cairo, is leaving to-day, via Port Said, for France, where he will spend the summer months. M. Campon, second secretary at the French Agency, will act as Consul-General during his at seuce.
Baron Max Oppenheim left Cairo to-day for Alexandria, where he will embark for Europe. Baron Oppenheim will spend the summer at Obergassel, Germany, returning to Egypt towards the end of October.
Dr. Antoine Comanos Parbai will leave for Europe on the 29th inst.

Dr. Wigham, of Port Said, has just been in cribed as an Avocat Cour d'Appel. Dr. Wigbam, who is an English lawyer of some yaars' standing, purposes, we understand, to practise in the Court of H.B.M.'s Consal General at Port Said.
Said Bey Shukeir, of the Sudan Administration, left Cairo yesterday, accompanied by bis family, for the Lebanon, where they will spend the summer season.

div.head: EXTRAORDINARY SCENE IN THE DUMA. MINISTRY ASKED TO RESIGN

div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, June 22. Duma --The Ministers of Justice and of the Interior made speeches defending the conduct of the police, but were bowled down amid execrations and shouts of murderers, massacremongers, and "Resign" ! A deputy. Prince Urassoff, ex assistant Minister of the Interior, created a sensation in the House by revealing an inflammatory proclamation printed by the Goverment department.
(Reuter) ST. PETERSBURG, June 22.
majority, demanding the resignation of the Ministry and the formation of a Government responsible to the Duma.
(Router) ST. PETERSBURG, June 22. The Dama bas adopted a motion calling for the creation of a responsible Mioistry. (8.) THE UNITED STATES HORRIFIED.

WASHINGTON, June 22. The Senate passed a resolution stating that the people of the United States were borrified at the massacres of the Jews in Russia and extend their hearty sympathy to the bereaved.
(Reuter)

div.head: KING HAAKON'S CORONATION.
div.p: CHRISTIANIA, Jane 22. | King Haakon and Queen Maud were crowned to-day in Trondhjem Cathedral in accordance with the imposing and ancient ceremonial.
The Prince and Princess of Wales and representatives of all States except Sweden were present.

The Bishop of Trondbjem and the Premier, jointly, placed the crown on King Haakon's head, the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Interior, and War, presenting respectively the soeptre, orb, and unsheathed sword.

Qneen Maud was subsequently crowned in a similar manner. Their Majesties were deeply moved. The President of the Storthing, at the conclusion of the ceremony, called out "God save the King and Qneon," and the whole assemb'y joined with him. (Reuter)
LONDON, Jone 22. King Edward ordered the bells to be rong E at Windsor in honour of the Coronation of the King and Queen of Norway. Salates were fired in many places throughout the United King
(Reuter)
TRONDHJEM, June 22. The coronation of King Haakon was very imposing,
dom.
SULTAN SIGNS CONVENTION.
TANGIER, June 22. The Sultan bas signed the Algeciras Convention
(Router)
TANGIER, June 22. The Sultan signed the protocol of the Algeoiras Conference on the 18th inst. (Havas)
SPEECH BY MR. CHURCHILL.

LONDON, June 22. Mr. Churcbill, at a banquet at the New Reform Club, dwelt on the necessity of dealing cautiously with the South Africa difficulties and of immediately abolishing Chinese labour. He appealed to Liberals for the continuance of their confidence in view of the imminence of the granting of a responsible government to the Transvaal and the necessity for preventing & violent economic collapse meanwbile.
Sic M. West Ridgeway's Transvaal and Orangia Constitution committee has concluded its labours.
(Reuter)

div.head: ANGLO GERMAN FRIENDSHIP.
div.p: London, June 23. The Anglo-German Friendship Committee entertained the German editors at a bar qnet. Lord Avebury presided. Mr. Loraburn proposed the toast of Anglo-German friendship. The speakers inoluded Mr. Bryce. (Reuter)

div.head: COTTON WORKERS' INCREASED WAGES.
div.p: New York, June 22. The cotton manufacturers of Massachussetts bave given their employees an increase of wages amounting to 14%, from 2nd July.

div.head: L'AFFAIRE DREYFUS
div.p: Paris, June 22. 1 The reporter in the Dreyfus case has recommended the case being sent before a council of war.
(Havas

div.head: RACING
div.p: LONDON, Jone 22. Hardwicke Stakes. Wombwell 1. Kuroki 2. Malaa broke down. Three ran. (Router)
H. H. ARRIVAL IN VIENNA.
VIENNA, June 22. The Khedive has arrived. - (Router)

THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR. Me. Helbawi Bey and Mr. Moberly have left Cairo for Denishwai, and will examine the locality where the affair took place in the course of to-day. The number of witnesses for the prosecution amounts to 29, including the British officers, their driver, and their guide The total number of accused is 59, of whom eight are still at large.
One Equadron of the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons and a detachment of the M.M.P. left Abbassieh at 7 20 a.m. to day for Chibin-el-Kom to be present doring the trial.

The officers of the Mounted latentry company paid a visit to Sheikh Ali Maklad of Kamsbeesh on the 20th inst. and took tea with the sheikh, whose son, Mohamed Ali, made a speech of a very complimentary Datore, emphasi-ing the remarkable restraint shown by the troops and their officers after the Denishwai incident and regretting that strangers should have been so cruelly treated by an ignorant mob. The commanding officer of the company returned thanks to the sheikh for bis kindness and courtesy. The mamour of Tala was present at the function.

We hear that by an arrangement with the Abyssinian Government the column which recently left Kassala in porsuit of Hailo Miriam was permitted to cross the Abyssinan frontier at Umrage, near the Bahr es Salam and Augereb rivers, and advance to Mar Gabta, some 40 miles within Abyssinian territory.

Here the column met the Dedjszmatoh (commander of the right wing) Gagsassa, who had encountered and slain Hailo Miriam and restored 40 captives. The Abyssinians are busily bunting up the remainder of the band and hope to be able to restore all the prisoners in the near future.

PETITION TO THE PREMIER

Nagaib Bey Sbakrs, advocate and proprietor of the 'Istiklal" magazine, Cairo, sends as copy of a petition which he sabmitted yester day to the President of the Council of Ministera, on behalf of the inhabitants of Helouan.

The petition se's forth that whilomanyimprovements have teen made during the last five years in Cairo and the neighbouring distriots, even in the desert, Helogan, which is one of the most beautiful towns of Egypt, is still greatly in need of improvement.

The petitioner asserts that the Helosan branch of the Delta Light Railway is still in a very defective condition. There is a great difference, he says, in every respe st, between this line and the Matarieh railway. It is true that the latter belongs to the State Railway Administration, which spares no effort to keep its trains and stations in good order, but the Government can compel the Delta Light Railway Company to either improve its Helouan line or give up its concession.
After pointing out that people find great diffioulties in travelling from Cairo to Helonan and vioe-versa, Sbakra Bey, on bebalf of the people of Helouan, makes the following requests :
2. To bring the Heloaan line ap to the | standard of tha Matarieb railway in material, rolling-stook and personnel.

3. To construot two roads for motor cars at Helouan, one to the Nile and the other to the foot of the mountain ; which scheme might be undertaken by a company composed of some of the chief land-owners of Helouan, if the Government would not enter apon it.
4. If the Delta Light Railway Company refuses to carry out the required improvements the Government will have to purchase its Helouan line and place it under the State Railway Administration.

We should like to poʻnt out that the Helonan line, while still in need of improvement, is in al far better condition than two years ago. As for Shakra Bay's suggestion that a train should leave for Helouan overy half-hour, we have little doubt that the financial result of such an alteration of the time-table would be decidedly | unplexadt. Halosan is, after all, not large town, the passenger traffi) falls off in sommer, and the goods traffic is not very important. As for the "motor-roads," how are they to pay ! Will the bypothetioal company levy tolls on motors, or how will it reimburse itself for the expenses of construction ? The petitioner does not seem to as to have weighed the financial consequences of his proposals.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: Colonel J. Magill, M.D., C.B., R.A.M.C., Principal Medioal Officer in Egypt, leaves Cairo on Wednesday next, 27th inst., en ronto to Crete and Cyprae, to make the annual inspection of barrasks and hospitals at those stations. Daring the absence of Colonel Magill, the duties of Officiating Principal Medical Officer will be performed by Lieut.-Col. H. K. Allport, M.D., R.A.M.C.

The following officers of the 2nd Roya Inniskilling Pasiliers have been granted leave of absence, on private affairs : Captain J. Evans, Captain J. H. Byrno, Lient. J. B. Matthews-Donaldson, Lieat. G. C. Adams, Lieat. G. M. Jennings, 2ad-Lient. Randall G. Ball, and 2nd-Lieut. C. E. G. Vernon.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: To-morrow afternoon there will be the debut of three new artistes, Signorina Adriana Lory, first soprano of the Castellano company, Big. Battaini, first tenor, and Sig. Pompa, baryton. The vocal part of the programme will commence at 6.30 p.m.
In the morning at 10.30 there will be a grand orchestral concert, including among other items Beethoven's 5th symphonie.
The following are the programmes for the morning and afternoon respectively :Marche-Tannhauser-Wagner Ballet-Sylvia-Delibes Danza Slave-Gianni Galletti Sifonia No. 5 op. 67- Beethoven
Allegro con brio-Adagio non troppo allegro
Marche-Revenant de la revue-Desormes Valse--La Housardo-Ganne Ouverture-Guglielmo Tell-Rossini Ballata dell'opera-Rigoletto pour tenor-Mr. Bat
taini Romanza--Faust Baryten-Mr. Pompa Romanza- Tosca Vissi d'arté-Mlle Lery Romanza-Toses Lucean le stelle Tenor-Mr. Battaini Duetto Cavalleria Rusticana
(Mlle Lery
| Mr. Battaini Ballet Egyptian pour orchestre-Luigini,

NOCTURNAL ARREST.
* EXCITING CHASE IN CAIRO.
We bave received the following communication from a correspondent in Cairo :

Yesterday morning, at about 3 o'clock, an | Englishman was returbing from a bachelor's dinner and bridge party, and on passing the Sharia Madabogh, close to the now premises of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, be noticed a number of suspicious characters loitering round.
Anticipating some fun, our informant waited in a dark cort er for developments in the hope of perhaps assisting in the capture of some noted Anarchist or more probably a raid on a gambling hell.

His patience was rewarded eventually: the too conspicuous detectives (sic) almost imme diately stopped a native lady who resembled the foolish virgins in not having her lamp barning, and after submitting ber to a close examination, possibly to see it she possessed any bombs, she was allowed to proceed. Scarcely bad she proceeded 50 yards, however, befora there was a cry of "imaikoa" |(equivalent to "Stop thief") and the whole posse of detectives started rapning down the street towards Sharia Boulac with, naturally, the Englishman in hot pursuit.

The chase, however, was not organised for the benefit of the lady, as might be presamed by our foregoing remarks. The "eagle eye" | of the secret service had unearthed a suspected criminal, or Anarchist, heaven knows from where, and as the quarry had 'gone away" as smartly as any Reynard from cover, the posse went off like hounds on a hot scent.

Our friend the Englishman dropped out at the first lap and finding a carriage immediate ly opposite the English Church followed up the chase to the building in course of constraction behind the Egyptian telegraph offices in the Sharia Boolse: the name of the driver of the carriage was Said Ahmed Ali, bis number 3892, ant the number of his cab 1077. The pursued was run to earth in the chantiers" | already mentioned and our informant arrived in time to see him bandled into a cab with three lasty guardians who showed scant courtesy; as a matter of fact one was dietinctly heard to ask for a rope !

No sooner had our Englishman arrived on the scene than he way surrounded by that part of the posse who ware not occupied with the supposed oriminal and promptly arrested with out any enquiry, - a respectably dressed Bng. Jishman, who spoke Italian and Arabic too well to allow for the momeat the idea of any misunderstanding, was arrested by a crowd of | ignorant secret service agents. He was bundled into his own c.b again with ghuffi No. 10 of ba Ismailia quarter gripping his right wrist in a totally uncalled-for manner and a police spy named Mohamed Sadik on the left. Towering over him was a Baropean, seemingly Maltese, whose name was unobtainable. The manner in which our inform unt was handled was too rough for words: he says his fighting weight is 9 stone 6, so it is difficult to imagine wby three strong men should be required to hold him, more particularly as he did not resist in the slightest, well knowing that he could easily clear himself of any complicity with the fagitive. As a matter of fact the victim is still feeling the results of his rough bandling, although it is jast to say he was not truck. "

On arriving at the Abdəea caracol our informant presented his card to the officer on duty and immediately received from that gentleman the greatest courtesy : the supposed criminal was asked if he knew the Englishman and promptly disclaimed any knowledge of having seen him before. Our friend the Britisher, who is a very peppery individual, then started roundly rating the whole assembly and insisted on immediate release, which was strongly opposed by the Maltese gentleman, but thanks to the courtesy of the officer in charge of the caracol he was permitted to depart. He was, however obliged to pay himself for the carriage in which he had been so roughly bundled.

A fall explanation and complete satistaetion for this outrage would feem to be necessary : that a law abiding person, only too anxious to be of assistance to the polioe, and manifesting a perfectly legitimate curiosity during an excit|ing occurence, should be arrested without the | slightest chance of justification and handled

like a felon by an ill-conditioned band of so-called secret police is intolerable, and despite our duty to assist in opholding a public body we are compelled to criticise the action of the police in this matter. The gentleman from whom we have this complaint | is a member of the Press and desires a fall enquiry into the matter. One thing is pretty certain, that had be not defended himself very vigorously (with his tongue), he would be at the present moment in "durance

We should like to point out that while the agents of the secret police appear to have grossly expeeded their powers, & gentleman who indulged in games of hide and seek round dark corners at 2 a.m. in London or Paris, and joined anasked in the pursuit of a fogi. tive, would ran considerable risk of passing the night in the "lock-up," and the moral in our opinion is, when returning from a bachelor's party at 2 a.m.: GO STRAIGHT HOME, and remember the ancient proverb 'Curiosity killed the cat.'"

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
London, Jane 14. Lieutenant Colonel and Brovat Colonel 8t. G. Henry, C.B., the A 'jatant General of the Bgyptian Army, has been granted the sa batantive rank of colonel.

Major W. 8. R. May, Bast Yorkshire Regi. ment, latterly serving with the Egyptian Army, has gone on retired pay. He joined the gallant "Snappers" in May, 1885, wao promoted captain in 1893, major in 1904, and was employed with the Egyptian Army for the past seven years. He saw service in the Nile Expedition of 1899 (medal with clasp)
Captain Gardner, Royal Pasiliers, bas been formally seconded for servica with the Kbedive's army.

The 1st Battalion Royal Ioniskilling Fasiliers, Belfast, will troop the colours on Monday next in commemoration of the glorious part the old 27th Inniskillings played in the ever-memorable battle of Waterloo. The officers will give a dance the following evening. The 27th was distingaished at Waterloo by its heroio endurance in a hell of fire," and its terrible losses in killed and woanded.

The 2nd Battalion Leicestershire Regiment, Brevet Colonel E.R. Scott commanding, which go3g from Colchester to India next trooping Season, was last in "The Shiny" from 1876 to 1898, the two sacoeeding years being spont in Barmsh and Aden. It went from Ireland to Bgypt in 1900, and came home in the latter end of 1992. Its 1st Battalion, now at Belgaum, will return home in turn this coming relief 8888on. It was in South Africa when the Boer War broke out, and shared a gallant part in | the defence of Ladysmith and the actions of
Tulana Hill and Lombard's Kop, which preceded the investment of that place.

It is authoritatively stated that the new army scheme, the full details of which will be given by Mr. Haldane next month, will include provision for the long-talked-of territorial army for home defence, and a foreign service army for duty in India, Egypt and the Colonies. The army as it stands will be redece by 43 rogalar batteries of horse and field artillery, and these will be replaced by militia batteries, which necessarily must be able to go on foreiga sørvioe if required to do so; the infantry will be reduced by 10,000 men, and the Army Service Corps by twenty companies. The volunteerr, yeomanry, and militia will be consolidatedan utter impossibility to anyone who understands anything about the personnel of those bodies—and a reduction will be made in the strength of the yeomanry. In short, the scheme, so far as is known about it, is a re-bash of some of Mr. Arnold Forster's fads, with nothing to recommend it, save a false sconomy. The outlook of those who will suffer in pay and promotion is by no means reassaring.

It appears that the now 18-pounder field gan has a tendency to turc tartle" under certain conditions owing to the centre of gravity being considerably above the axle. This in turn is due to the peouliar construction of the gun and the recoil apparatus. On broken ground, when palled round suddenly, the gun inolines to topple over, and several nasty spills hsve resalted at Tidworth and elsewhere one case being very unfortanately attended by fatal resulta. Oa active service this woald be a very serious matter. Experts of the Ordnance Dapartment are inquiring into the defect. It is officially stated thist out of the 150 field batteries now on the establishment only 109 will be equipped with the new field gon, whilst 21 of the existing 38 batteries of the Royal Horse Artillery will receive the new 13-pounder. la artillery circle, the threatened reduction of the Royal Regiment is bitterly resented, and condemned.
The programme for the building of several battleships of the Dreadnought type is to be oat dowo, for the sake of economy.
